block.p: 37 Are Killed in Attack On London Mass Transit Bomb explosions tore through three subway trains and a red-painted double-decker bus in a coordinated terror attack during London's morning rush hour, killing at least 37 people, injuring about 700 and leaving the city stunned and bloodied but oddly stoic.

Investigators searching for clues in the attacks say the three bombs used in the Underground appeared to have been detonated by timers, not suicide bombers, and that a fourth device may have been intended for a target other than the city bus that it destroyed.

The past 24 hours for Prime Minister Tony's Blair of Britain have been a roller-coaster ride from triumph to tragedy. Mr. Blair flew back to London after the bombings a day after opening the summit meeting of the Group of 8 major industrial nations in Scotland and after London was awarded the 2012 Olympics.

The bombings in London knocked the meeting of major industrial nations off its focus on global warming and African poverty and turned it into a forum for world leaders to pledge unity in confronting terrorism.

Egyptian Diplomat Killed in Iraq The insurgent group Al Qaeda in Iraq said it had killed Egypt's ambassador-designate in Iraq, five days after gunmen had seized him on a street in western Baghdad where he had driven alone to buy a local newspaper.

Genocide Suspects Still at Large Western diplomats and military officials are struggling to explain why two Bosnian Serb leaders indicted in the killing of Muslim men and boys during the Bosnian war remain at large.

Army Report on Prisoner Health An Army assessment has found no evidence of systemic problems in medical care of prisoners at American detention centers in Iraq, Afghanistan and Cuba, Army officials said.

Terror Alert Level Is Raised For Transportation System Concerned about a ''copycat attack,'' federal officials raised the alert level for rail, subway and bus systems, prompting more police patrols, searches by bomb-sniffing dogs and inspections of packages.
A Plan for the Great Lakes A coalition of government agencies, business and environmental groups has offered a blueprint for improving the health of the Great Lakes.

Drug Discount Fight Pharmaceutical companies are pouring millions of dollars into a campaign to defeat a measure on the November ballot in California that would pressure them to lower drug prices for millions of residents.

Hurricane Hits Caribbean Hurricane Dennis swirled into a powerful Category 4 storm, with its fierce winds and rain killing at least four people in southwestern Haiti as the storm lashed the Caribbean. The hurricane's winds grew to 135 m.p.h. as it sideswiped Jamaica.

State Revenues Rebound State revenues rose in the last year as the nation's economy produced more sales of goods and services and generated more income for individuals and corporations, the National Governors Association reported.

Capitol Hill Prepares For Battle The Senate is in recess, and President Bush has yet to select a candidate for the Supreme Court vacancy, but scores of aides on Capitol Hill are knee-deep in preparations for upcoming nominations fight.

Kidnap Suspect Kept Blog Joseph E. Duncan III, the convicted sex offender accused of kidnapping Dylan Groene, 9, and Dylan's sister Shasta, 8, from their rural Idaho home, spent months on the Internet documenting his internal struggle with right and wrong.

Newest Crop of OfficersIs First Majority Minority The 1,600 recruits who will become police officers next week make up the first graduating class in the history of the New York Police Department in which members of minorities make up the majority. The difference is seen by many as a significant marker in the department's slow racial evolution.

Retired Detectives Granted Bail A federal judge in Brooklyn ordered two retired city detectives charged with murdering for the mob released on bail, saying the evidence was ''not strong'' and citing concerns with the statute of limitations.
Chinatown Bank War Grows A Commerce Bank branch opening in Chinatown today will have an extraordinary 7,500 safe deposit boxes, reflecting the highly competitive bank branch war in the neighborhood.

Diabetes Database Proposal New York City health officials have proposed that all city laboratories be compelled to provide the results of tests that measure blood sugar levels to the health department, in an effort to better understand how diabetics manage their disease. The department is the first in the country to propose such a mandate.
Vito J. Titone A judge who was a firm liberal voice on the New York State Court of Appeals, he was 76.

Markets Fall and Recover Markets across Europe, which were thrown into turmoil after the deadly rush-hour explosions in London, recouped much of their losses by day's end. American markets ended the day slightly higher.

Ex-Broker to Be Retried Theodore C. Sihpol III, a former Bank of America broker who was acquitted last month on 29 of 33 criminal charges tied to improper trading of mutual funds, faces a retrial on the four counts on which jurors could not agree.

KPMG Faces Civil Suits KPMG, the accounting firm being investigated over the sale and promotion of bogus tax shelters, faces civil battles in federal and state courts across the country by dozens of individual investors who say the company's dealings have cost them billions of dollars.
Editorials: London under attack; protections for the United States; fighting terrorism at Gleneagles; the Olympic Games.
Columns: Paul Krugman, Thomas L. Friedman.
